title: 113_s1204
content: The Act may be cited as the "Health Care Conscience Rights Act". It includes findings related to health care rights. Congress finds that the protection of conscience rights is a fundamental principle deeply rooted in the history and traditions of the United States, as evidenced by various federal laws. Following the enactment of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA), the Federal Government has imposed requirements that infringe on the rights of conscience for those offering or purchasing health coverage. PPACA provides exemptions for some religious groups but fails to provide statutory protection for individuals seeking to offer or purchase health coverage with religious objections. Conscience rights protections for health care providers are crucial for civil rights in Federal law and the functioning of the US healthcare system. Discrimination against faith-based healthcare providers jeopardizes access to quality care for vulnerable populations. The Affordable Care Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 1566, which focuses on respecting conscience rights in health coverage. SEC. 245A. CIVIL ACTION FOR CERTAIN VIOLATIONS. A qualified party, including the Attorney General or any affected person, can seek relief in a civil action for designated violations without needing to exhaust administrative remedies. Designated violations include specific violations of healthcare acts. In civil actions for designated violations, relief can be sought without exhausting administrative remedies. Parties can include governmental entities, and relief may include money damages. The court can grant necessary legal and equitable relief, including declaratory relief and compensatory damages.
